ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned so much about Japan in terms of art and culture and history. The class also taught me how much you can learn from art and enjoy art in an academic context.
I've acquired a deep cultural understanding of Japanese art from the Jomon period to the Kamakura period. I've also learned how to apply context to help analyze certain art pieces.
I was introduced to the history of art in Japan and examined different time periods.
I learned about early Japanese art! And got better at analyzing art objects and writing about them.
A lot of exposure to Japanese art from prehistory to the medieval period
Japanese history & culture
I learned more about Japanese art history
it was a survey course about japanese art. learned about their history, art, culture and religion

This course allows very thorough, concentrated consideration of themes in Japanese art over time.  Images that now seem ubiquitous become far more fascinating in the context of geographical location, foreign influences, and deeply pondering changes over time. Unlike more didactic courses, this one encourages personal speculation and productive disagreement, which makes learning the material much more engaging than simple memorization.
I learned about Japanese history.
I learned about ancient Japanese art, focusing specifically on Shinto and Buddhist ceramics and paintings.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think the discussion sections in the course were a fun place to discuss topics and the lectures were very interesting to listen to. Sometimes it would have been helpful to have a few more words with info on the slides.

This course had many strengths. I appreciated how the class was recorded in addition to the live lecture because it allowed me to refer back to class material when needed. I thought the structure of class assignments (brief notes) was also very fair and engaging.
Honestly, this course is great. I love any classes taught by Prof. Yiengpruksawan.

Strengths: Mimi is great - she is enthusiastic about the material and happy to talk with students. And a wide range of material was covered in the class; it felt like a good overview. I also liked the brief notes as an informal way to learn more about individual works of art.
Weaknesses: I think because we covered so much, it sometimes felt like we moved quickly from thing to thing and they didn't all relate to each other.

Strengths:
- Mimi! She is such a caring, knowledgeable professor. She gives prompt, thoughtful feedback.
Weaknesses:
- more students might have taken the class or been more engaged if it wasn't at 9:25 am
The course is great. Wouldnt reccomdend taking it if your not interested in the subject matter.
i love prof mimi's classes. she is so knowledgeable and meets every student where they are and works to make sure each student retains information in the way that is best for their learning style

The course really allows individual exploration; while periodic written assignments are required throughout, the student always has the option to write on whatever they find interesting in the format that seems appropriate. This format redefines engagement, especially compared to other art history courses.
The course was flexible and relaxed, so it was very conducive to learning.

Strength: this course provides insight about an area of art history that is often not discussed in traditional art history surveys.
Weakness: the majority of the images for this course were unlabeled (no title, no artist / culture, no size, no medium) which made it difficult to take notes and then write essays on these objects.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone interested in art or history!

yes, I would recommend this course to any student at yale, regardless of major. Not only did this course help me develop my visual analysis skills, but it helped me develop a greater appreciation for the arts.
Yes. I'm a STEM major and prof. Yiengpruksawan makes me want to switch to humanities.
Yes! An interesting lecture that is pretty low key.
Yes! But, you should be interested in the subject material
Yes, if they're interested in art history
If they love Japanese art.

Yes! Mimi is a delightful instructor who really cares about all of her students. She knows so much about the field and is willing to help you understand the content. She was my best professor this semester & the workload of the course is easily managable.
absolutely prof mimi is one of the best at Yale i have ever encountered

Absolutely. The course is incredibly thoughtful, in depth, and provides fascinating context to the thought systems and images that pervade Japan, even today. Mimi is very encouraging of students to contribute their own thoughts in an environment that quite successfully becomes both non-stressful and intellectually inquisitive.
Yes! Mimi is great and the material is very interesting.

If a student was interested in Japanese art and writing more creative essays then I would recommend this course. This course does also require some amount of self-discipline to do the readings and the essays as it's more free form.
